audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a suspenseful electronic dance music track. Then, a male speaker says "That saddle," followed by another male speaker saying, "perfectly saddle. Stupid saddle." Another male speaker asks, "what are you doing?" to which the second male speaker responds, "mate. Wanna talk about saddles?" The first speaker inquires, "Oh, we're filming a Bike or Tuesdays, alright yeah? Alright. Good." He then continues, "We got a bunch of saddles here, which one is the best for road cycling? Which one is the best for me?" The first male speaker says "This one." Then the second male speaker states, "I'm not riding that," then transitions to "The roll of a saddle."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the role of a bicycle seat in supporting and stabilizing the pelvis, suggesting engaging the "sit bones or ischial pubic rami," sometimes both depending on the "pelvic orientation," explaining whether it is anteriorly or posteriorly rotated. He states this will determine the saddle shape that will work best.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a conversational tone, discussing the need for a pressure relief channel on a bicycle seat. He emphasizes that not everyone needs one and describes it as the hole cut in the middle intended to "offload soft tissue," mentioning studies about "sterility," "erectile dysfunction," and "nastier things."

The clip starts with a male speaker, in an informative and slightly conversational tone, discussing how certain types of saddles might be uncomfortable if the rider has pelvic rotation. He continues, mentioning that riders might sit off to one side due to various reasons like insufficient foot support, excessive saddle height, or reach, or even to alleviate soft tissue pressure. The speaker notes that riders may sit askew to make themselves comfortable.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing bike saddles. He describes the types of saddles that riders tend to purchase, mentioning Pro Griffon and Specialized Toupe as examples, and notes his lack of success with flatter saddles. He explains the pelvic alignment and spinal flexion issues associated with the flatter saddles, and ultimately concludes it is not good. The audio clip concludes with the speaker abruptly saying “you.”

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing the prevalence of a saddle brand's compensation system, humorously avoiding naming the developer. He then clarifies that viewers likely want to find the best saddle due to discomfort, raising the question of why they are considering a new saddle. The speaker believes saddle discomfort mostly stems from bad positions, not saddles. He adds that saddle sores result from asymmetrical bike interactions, which he believes results in saddle sores primarily on one side. He concludes, noting that bilateral sores point to extremely poor positioning.

The clip features one male speaker discussing saddles, specifically mentioning the "Pro Griffon" and saddles from Specialized and Bontrager. He emphasizes the importance of features like flatness and a pressure relief channel. He mentions that most of his customers end up using this saddle. In the background, we hear music playing with a somewhat somber tone.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing saddle fitting, noting that the "152 width tends to be a little bit too wide." He then challenges the common saddle fitting systems, explaining that they are often "driven by measuring sit bone width" but, in his experience, "sit bone width doesn't really have that much now saying in saddle selection." The speaker's tone is informative and slightly critical.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the "noseless saddle" concept. He states it is a "very, very popular concept" and describes a design philosophy he has "increasing difficulty with." The speaker elaborates on issues stemming from "the excessive width of the rear portion of the saddle." He states this "tends to drive riders to the nose of the saddle," which is "a problem because the nose doesn't exist."

The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining something marketed as enabling a more aerodynamic position. He describes the ability to get a "nose of the saddle" further forward and mentioning UCI's 5 centimeter rule. He further explains that an "average Joe" shouldn't try to push the saddle forward because it only puts more strain on the knee.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing bike saddles, mentioning the "Pro Stealth", "Specialized Power", and "Prologo Dimension". He expresses frustration with "noseless saddles" and their applicability for everyday cyclists. He argues that professional cyclists' use of such products shouldn't be the main factor for consumer choices, as they are often sponsored to use certain products. The speaker then states he's having increasing difficulty with noseless saddles and has "a hell of a lot more success" with traditional flat saddles.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing bicycle saddles, specifically noting that he sells them to the right person on the right bike, mentioning an "ISM PM 3.1" saddle. He specifies that this is a time trial and triathlon saddle designed to "load a different part of the pelvis," further forward, and meant for riding in "a more anteriorly rotated" position. He speaks in an informative and descriptive tone.

The audio clip features a man speaking with a slightly argumentative tone, expressing his opinion on a specific saddle type, stating that it "doesn't really have any place on a road bike." He elaborates on its perceived inadequacy in supporting the pelvis, suggesting it's often a last resort for riders experiencing genital numbness due to improper bike positioning. He emphasizes that if numbness occurs with such a saddle, it indicates a problem beyond the saddle itself and recommends a professional position assessment. He concludes by stating that this type of saddle should only be for triathlon and time trials.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing the information about saddles as "just the tip of the iceberg," suggesting the need for further discussion. He then invites the listeners to ask questions in the comments about saddle fitting, promising to answer them. A second speaker, also male, adds, "And subscribe for more," repeating the same phrase afterward to end the clip.
